courses.title: Beginner English
courses.description: Start your journey with basic vocabulary and grammar. Perfect for absolute beginners.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the Beginner English course! In this course, you will learn basic vocabulary and grammar to help you start speaking English.

sections.title: Present Simple Tense
sections.content: The present simple tense is used to describe habits, unchanging situations, general truths, and fixed arrangements. Example: I eat breakfast every day.

sections.title: Past Simple Tense
sections.content: The past simple tense is used to talk about completed actions in the past. Example: I visited my grandmother last weekend.

sections.title: Future Simple Tense
sections.content: The future simple tense is used to describe actions that will happen in the future. Example: I will go to the store tomorrow.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the Beginner English course. Keep practicing what you've learned and continue your journey to becoming fluent in English.

courses.title: Intermediate English
courses.description: Enhance your skills with intermediate grammar and conversation practice.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the Intermediate English course! In this course, you will build on your basic knowledge and learn more complex grammar and vocabulary.

sections.title: Present Continuous Tense
sections.content: The present continuous tense is used to describe actions that are happening right now or are ongoing. Example: I am studying English.

sections.title: Past Continuous Tense
sections.content: The past continuous tense is used to describe actions that were happening at a specific moment in the past. Example: I was watching TV when the phone rang.

sections.title: Future Continuous Tense
sections.content: The future continuous tense is used to describe actions that will be happening at a specific moment in the future. Example: I will be working at 9 AM tomorrow.

sections.title: Present Perfect Tense
sections.content: The present perfect tense is used to describe actions that have happened at an unspecified time or that started in the past and continue to the present. Example: I have finished my homework.

sections.title: Past Perfect Tense
sections.content: The past perfect tense is used to describe actions that were completed before another action in the past. Example: I had finished my homework before I went out.

sections.title: Future Perfect Tense
sections.content: The future perfect tense is used to describe actions that will be completed before a specific moment in the future. Example: I will have finished my project by next week.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the Intermediate English course. Keep practicing what you've learned to further improve your skills and confidence in English.

courses.title: Advanced English
courses.description: Master complex grammar and advanced vocabulary to become fluent.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the Advanced English course! In this course, you will master complex grammar structures and advanced vocabulary to achieve fluency.

sections.title: Present Perfect Continuous Tense
sections.content: The present perfect continuous tense is used to describe actions that started in the past and are still continuing or have recently stopped. Example: I have been studying for three hours.

sections.title: Past Perfect Continuous Tense
sections.content: The past perfect continuous tense is used to describe actions that were ongoing in the past before another action. Example: I had been reading for an hour before she arrived.

sections.title: Future Perfect Continuous Tense
sections.content: The future perfect continuous tense is used to describe actions that will be ongoing up until a specific point in the future. Example: By next month, I will have been working at this company for a year.

sections.title: Advanced Conditionals
sections.content: Advanced conditionals are used to describe complex hypothetical situations and their consequences. Example: If I had known about the meeting, I would have attended.

sections.title: Advanced Passive Voice
sections.content: The passive voice is used to focus on the action rather than the subject. Advanced passive constructions can add nuance to your writing. Example: The project had been completed before the deadline was announced.

sections.title: Reported Speech
sections.content: Reported speech is used to relay what someone else has said. Example: She said that she was going to the store.

sections.title: Advanced Vocabulary and Idioms
sections.content: Expand your vocabulary with advanced words and idiomatic expressions. Example: 'Break the ice' means to initiate conversation in a social setting.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the Advanced English course. Keep practicing what you've learned to maintain and further improve your fluency.

courses.title: Business English
courses.description: Learn English for professional settings, including meetings, presentations, and emails.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the Business English course! This course will help you learn the language skills needed for professional settings, including meetings, presentations, and emails.

sections.title: Meeting Language
sections.content: Learn essential phrases and vocabulary for participating in meetings. Example: 'Could you please clarify that point?'

sections.title: Presentation Skills
sections.content: Develop your presentation skills with useful phrases and tips. Example: 'Today, I am going to talk about our new project.'

sections.title: Email Etiquette
sections.content: Master the art of writing professional emails. Example: 'Dear Mr. Smith, I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to inquire about...'

sections.title: Telephone Conversations
sections.content: Improve your telephone communication skills. Example: 'Good morning, this is John from XYZ Company. How can I help you today?'

sections.title: Networking
sections.content: Learn how to network effectively in professional settings. Example: 'It's a pleasure to meet you. What line of work are you in?'

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the Business English course. Use these skills to communicate effectively in professional settings.

courses.title: Travel English
courses.description: Prepare for your travels with essential phrases and vocabulary for various situations.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the Travel English course! This course will help you learn essential phrases and vocabulary for various travel situations.

sections.title: At the Airport
sections.content: Learn useful phrases for navigating the airport. Example: 'Where is the check-in counter?'

sections.title: Hotel Check-in
sections.content: Master the phrases needed for checking into a hotel. Example: 'I have a reservation under the name of Smith.'

sections.title: Asking for Directions
sections.content: Learn how to ask for and understand directions. Example: 'Can you please tell me how to get to the nearest subway station?'

sections.title: Ordering Food
sections.content: Get comfortable with ordering food in restaurants. Example: 'I would like to order the grilled chicken, please.'

sections.title: Shopping
sections.content: Learn phrases for shopping and bargaining. Example: 'How much does this cost?'

sections.title: Emergency Situations
sections.content: Know what to say in case of emergencies. Example: 'I need help. I lost my passport.'

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the Travel English course. Use these skills to make your travels smoother and more enjoyable.

courses.title: English for Kids
courses.description: Fun and engaging lessons to help children learn English through games and activities.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to the English for Kids course! This course will help children learn English through fun games and activities.

sections.title: Basic Vocabulary
sections.content: Learn basic words for everyday objects. Example: 'apple, ball, cat.'

sections.title: Colors and Shapes
sections.content: Learn the names of colors and shapes. Example: 'red, blue, circle, square.'

sections.title: Numbers and Counting
sections.content: Learn numbers and how to count. Example: 'one, two, three.'

sections.title: Animals
sections.content: Learn the names of common animals. Example: 'dog, cat, elephant.'

sections.title: Family Members
sections.content: Learn the names of family members. Example: 'mother, father, sister, brother.'

sections.title: Everyday Activities
sections.content: Learn phrases for everyday activities. Example: 'brushing teeth, eating breakfast.'

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Congratulations! You have completed the English for Kids course. Keep practicing what you've learned and have fun with English!

questions.question: What is the present simple tense used for?
options: Describing completed actions in the past

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct example of the present simple tense?
What is the past continuous tense used for?
options: Describing actions that were happening at a specific moment in the past
Describing completed actions in the past
questions.answer: Describing actions that were happening at a specific moment in the past

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct example of the past continuous tense?
options: I was eating breakfast when the phone rang.
questions.answer: I was eating breakfast when the phone rang.

questions.question: What is the present perfect tense used for?
options: Describing actions that happened at an unspecified time
Describing completed actions in the past
questions.answer: Describing actions that happened at an unspecified time

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct example of the present perfect tense?
What is the best way to start a formal email?
Which of the following is appropriate for a business meeting?
Which phrase would you use to ask for directions?
options: Can I have the bill, please?

questions.question: How do you say 'Thank you' in a polite manner?
What is the English word for 'chien'?
What is the color of the sky?
